alert.note: Alert for Carver; Scott; Sibley (Minnesota) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 22 at 10:01AM CDT until May 24 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Minneapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River near Jordan affecting Carver, Scott and Sibley Counties. Minnesota River at Savage affecting Dakota, Carver, Scott and Hennepin Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Minnesota... Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown, Blue Earth and Nicollet Counties. Sauk River at St. Cloud affecting Stearns County. Minnesota River At Morton affecting Redwood and Renville Counties. Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Lac qui Parle, Chippewa and Yellow Medicine Counties. .Forecast points continue falling with the exception of the Minnesota River at Jordan and Savage as the final flood wave moves downstream. This is also why the Mississippi at Saint Paul is having a extended crest as it is just downstream of the confluence of the two rivers. With no significant precipitation forecast for the next few days current trends are expected to continue. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM THIS MORNING TO TUESDAY EVENING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Minnesota River near Jordan. * WHEN...From this morning to Tuesday evening. * IMPACTS...At 25.0 feet, Low lying areas and some roads along the river begin to flood and private sanitary sewers may experience problems. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 945 AM CDT Sunday, the stage was 25.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise this afternoon to a crest of 25.1 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 25.1 feet on 04/06/1962. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
